intro: Acanthocalycium griseum, commonly known as the gray cactus or the Mexican nightshade cactus, is a species of cactus native to Mexico. It is characterized by its short, cylindrical stems that are typically covered in a layer of grayish-white wax. The plant produces small, yellow flowers that bloom in the evening, attracting nocturnal pollinators. It is drought-tolerant and thrives in well-draining soil, making it suitable for arid environments. Due to its unique appearance and hardy nature, it is often cultivated as an ornamental plant.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acanthocalycium griseum is primarily native to northern Mexico, specifically the states of Chihuahua and Coahuila. It thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, often found in rocky soils and limestone regions. This species is adapted to harsh desert conditions, including extreme temperatures and limited rainfall. It is commonly found in areas with sparse vegetation, such as scrublands and desert plains. Due to its unique appearance and habitat, it is a sought-after species among cactus enthusiasts and botanists.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acanthocalycium griseum was mainly introduced to the United States as an ornamental cactus due to its unique appearance and hardiness.
